title: 108_s2511
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004". It includes definitions for the Chimayo Water Supply System. The Act, known as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004", defines key terms such as Secretary, study area, system, and town related to the Chimayo Water Supply System feasibility study conducted by the Secretary of the Interior in cooperation with state and local authorities. The Secretary, in cooperation with state and local authorities, will conduct a feasibility study for a water supply system in Chimayo. This includes potable water transmission lines, pump stations, and storage reservoirs. Options for water supply include connection to the Espanola Water Filtration Facility and various regional or local sources. The feasibility study for a water supply system in Chimayo will explore options such as connecting to the Espanola Water Filtration Facility, utilizing local or regional sources, reusing/recycling water, and considering alternative water supplies. Lifecycle costs, including operation, maintenance, and treatment costs, will be determined. The study will determine the total lifecycle costs of the water supply system, including operation, maintenance, replacement, treatment costs, and management costs. The Secretary must complete the study within 3 years of the Act's enactment, with a 75 percent Federal cost share. Coordination with various agencies is required for the study. The Bureau of Reclamation, Bureau of Land Management, and US Geological Survey will conduct a feasibility study to determine water resources for the Town. This includes accessing necessary land and drilling exploratory wells. A report on the study results must be submitted to Congress within 1 year of completion. The feasibility study results must be submitted within 1 year of completion or 4 years after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary can provide emergency water supply development assistance to eligible entities in the study area for activities like hauling water and installing purification technology. The Secretary may provide assistance for activities such as hauling water, installing water purification technology, drilling wells, installing pump stations, storage reservoirs, transmission pipelines, distribution pipelines, emergency water supply systems, and other eligible activities as determined appropriate. The Secretary may provide assistance for various water-related activities, with a 75 percent Federal cost share. Other eligible activities may also be determined appropriate. Authorization of appropriations for sections 102 and 103 is specified for fiscal years 2005 through 2010. Funds for section 102 are $2,000,000, and for section 103, $3,000,000. Funds under section 102 cannot be used for water infrastructure construction. SEC. 202. ESPANOLA WATER FILTRATION FACILITY. The term "component" refers to water delivery infrastructure developments, while "facility" pertains to the Espanola water filtration facility. The Secretary of the Interior, through the Commissioner of Reclamation, is defined as the "Secretary." Financial assistance will be provided to Espanola, New Mexico, for constructing the Espanola water filtration facility to utilize imported water effectively. Financial assistance will be provided to the city of Espanola, New Mexico, for the construction of a water filtration facility. The facility will include presedimentation basins, an influent pump station, pretreatment facilities, filtration facilities, finished water storage facilities, a finished water booster pump station, sludge dewatering facilities, and potable water transmission lines. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for the study, planning, design, and construction of a water delivery infrastructure development for the Santa Clara and San Juan Pueblos of New Mexico, including potable water transmission lines and the use of reclaimed water to enhance water resources. The Federal government will fund 25% of the water delivery infrastructure development for Santa Clara and San Juan Pueblos, but funds cannot be used for operation or maintenance. SEC. 203. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $3,000,000 is authorized for the construction of the facility for fiscal years 2005 through 2009.
